title: Apprentice's Lottie Lion criticised by BBC over 'racist' WhatsApp comment on rival
text:

The BBC have slammed The Apprentice candidate Lottie Lion after she said "shut up Gandhi" to her rival Lubna Farham, who has Pakistani heritage.

The company said it told Lottie, 19, her comments were "wholly unacceptable" and left her in "no doubt about our view on this".

It comes as Lottie was branded "racist" for her message, which was sent in a WhatsApp group shared by the candidates and created after filming wrapped.

A BBC spokesperson said: "While this happened on a private messenger service once filming had concluded, the BBC nevertheless still expects the candidates to behave appropriately.

"The production company have looked into the issue and reported back, Lottie has been informed that her comments were wholly unacceptable and is in no doubt about our view on this."

(Image: BBC/Boundless)

(Image: BBC/Boundless)

Lottie has denied her comments were racist, and said they were taken out of context.

She told the Press Association: "My use of the word Gandhi was misinterpreted, it was as candidates in the group chat had been quoting Gandhi previously."

She added: "The comments were taken out of context, and I ask the public not to make judgment without knowing the full context.

"At the moment, I would like my focus to be on the show, and I'm not interested in negative media attention."

(Image: BBC / Boundless)

(Image: BBC / Boundless)

However, Lubna confirmed there was definitely conflict between her and Lottie, though she would not go into detail.

Speaking to Mirror Online after being fired by Lord Sugar, Lubna admitted that Lottie has "a lot to learn in terms of how to treat people".

The mum-of-two, who revealed she is no longer part of the nasty WhatsApp group, confessed she felt "paranoid" around the other candidates.

When asked about the race row, Lubna told us: "It has already been in the media so I don't think there's much more I can add to that.

"All I can say is I wish her well, she has a lot to learn in terms of how to treat people, but she is quite young and I'm sure that within this process she has learnt a lot and will take something from it.

(Image: BBC)

(Image: PA)

"I’m not going to sit here and lie and say that was wrong."

On whether the show had offered her any aftercare following the 'racist' comments, Lubna added: "It's not something that necessarily would be wise for me to talk about at this moment."

The Apprentice has been the subject of another race row this year, as the first four contestants to be fired were all people of colour: Lubna, Souleyman, Kenna Ngoma, and Shahin Hassan.

Souleyman Bah, who was eliminated last week, spoke to last year's winner Sian Gabbidon on her podcast The Wake Up Call about being subject to racist comments during filming.

(Image: mirror.co.uk)

He said: "I think there were comments that, you know, yeah… I won’t get into the details of it, but I think it was definitely what it was.

"I will counter that by saying it was ignorance, really. It’s definitely ignorant racism. I think there’s blatant racism and then there’s ignorant racism."

"I think my beef isn’t with the perpetrator per se, its more for what’s been done about it.

"It seems that I’m still waiting for the outcome."

(Image: BBC/Boundless)

A spokesperson for the show told MirrorOnline: “Which candidates return to the boardroom at the end of a task - and are therefore in the firing line - is determined by being on the losing team, and the project manager of that task deciding to take them back into the boardroom.

"The candidate's performance both on the task and in the boardroom are then key to Lord Sugar’s decision.”
description: Lottie reportedly told Lubna Farhan, who has Pakistani heritage, "shut up, Ghandi" in a Whatsapp group chat
